results.title: How to Claim Your Share of Facebook’s $725 Million Privacy Settlement
results.abstract: Anyone who had a U.S. Facebook account between May 2007 and December 2022 is eligible to apply, though payouts are likely to be small.

media.caption: The offices of Meta, Facebook’s parent company, in Menlo Park, Calif., in 2022.

results.byline: By Abbie VanSickle and Pam Belluck
results.title: The Abortion Pill Ruling: What’s Happened, What’s at Stake, What’s Next
results.abstract: The court is expected to weigh in on whether a commonly used pill, mifepristone, should remain widely available. Here is what’s at stake.

media.caption: Mifepristone is part of a two-drug regimen that now accounts for more than half of the abortions in the United States.
media.copyright: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

results.title: Airman Shared Sensitive Intelligence More Widely and for Longer Than Previously Known

media.caption: The first leak to Discord appeared to come less than 48 hours into Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.

results.abstract: Residents of Port Isabel said that their city was covered in grime following SpaceX’s rocket launch on Thursday. The city said there was no “immediate concern for people’s health.”

results.title: The Obscure G.O.P. Bookkeeper at the Center of the George Santos Mess

results.title: After 20 Years, an Arrest in the Murder of a Detective’s Daughter
results.abstract: Megan McDonald, whose father was a Police Department detective, was found dead near a dirt path outside Middletown, N.Y. This week, her former boyfriend was arrested.

media.caption: The search for Megan McDonald’s killer lasted more than 20 years.

results.title: ‘A Quick Death or a Slow Death’: Prisoners Choose War to Get Lifesaving Drugs
results.abstract: An estimated 20 percent of Russia prisoner recruits are H.I.V. positive. To some, the front lines seemed less risky than prisons where they said they were denied effective treatments.

results.title: N.F.L. Suspends Five Players for Gambling
results.abstract: Quintez Cephus and C.J. Moore of the Detroit Lions and Shaka Toney of the Washington Commanders were suspended indefinitely for betting on N.F.L. games, and two other Lions players will sit out six games for gambling violations.
